chapter.title: Discounts
chapter.para: In an ideal world you'd never have to give students a discount. They would all flock to your courses at full price. But discounts can form an integral part of your marketing strategy. Used well, they allow you to attract students who would not otherwise have enrolled at the full price. Used poorly, they represent income you give away to students who would have happily paid full price. In an ideal world, you will sell to each student at the maximum price they would have paid. This is called 'differential pricing' and one way to achieve it is through well placed discounts. It allows you to set your full price to be higher than you would normally, and target those individuals who would be discouraged at that price point with special offers.

This approach has several benefits to some types of colleges: it positions you as a premium service, it creates an impression that you are looking after certain special customers and it allows you to discount more deeply for certain demographics knowing that higher income is coming from others. As an example of this approach look at the airline industry: it is very unlikely that the person sitting next to you paid the same for their seat as you did. And airlines economic model is a lot like education; your product is completely perishable. Once the flight takes off or the class starts, those empty seats can never be sold.

section.title: Introduction to discounts

listitem.para: A discount is an onCourse marketing tool allowing you to sell a class at a reduced price.

varlistentry.term: What's the value of a discount?

listitem.para: A discount value may be applied in dollars, percentage or a change the fee to a set amount (where you specify the same fee that will apply for all classes eligible). All discount values are ex gst.

varlistentry.term: Who is Eligible for a discount?

orderedlist.title: Discount eligibility may be checked against any or all of the following discount parameters, all of which can be set in the discount feature in onCourse:

listitem.para: Students: Discounts may be offered to anyone, students under or over a certain age, students in a certain postcode, students with particular memberships such as staff member, or students with a concession such as a youth card.
Classes: Discounts may be offered to a Course (and all it's classes), a Class or, all current and pending classes.

Discount values: The discount itself may have a valid from or expiry date, or require students to enter a special promotional code. Discounts can be offered automatically when the student meets the discount requirement and may also be offered in conjunction with other discounts.
There are two main types of discounts for eligible enrolments.

Discounts not offered automatically: If a student does not know about a discount, they won't get it. If they know about it, they should enter a Promotional Code. The discount value should include a code and obviously marketing of this promotion will need to include the code.

Discounts offered automatically: If a student is eligible for a discount because they met the set criteria, the discount will automatically be offered. The discount value does usually require knowing a promotional code, but may include holding a certain type of concession card or membership.

section.para: Please note that your website may not currently have a place for students to enter a promotional code or the ability for students to provide their concession card details for automatic discounts because this is something that may not have been required at the time of website implementation. However these are features that can be added, should you request.

section.title: What is a concession?
section.para: These are the discounts you think of when you imagine children, seniors, disability card holders or unemployed discounts. These are discounts which can be given either as a percentage of the course fee, or as a fixed dollar figure. If you decide to give a percentage discount you can also set the minimum and maximum dollar discount which can be given. So you might to decide to give 10% off for seniors but cap it at $50 so that $800 course doesn't start to be discounted too heavily for you. Or a 2% discount which gives at least $5 off that $100 course so it doesn't appear too stingy.

Discounts can be given a start and end date. You might want a discount to continue indefinitely or you might want it to be a special one time offer valid for a certain period. onCourse gives you the choice.

Next comes the students entitled to a concession. You might find all students who have enrolled in the past, are over a certain age, live in a particular suburb or who have a seniors card. You aren't locking it to the students who currently fit the requirement: any student who later is entered into the system with the right age, suburb or discount type will be able to obtain that discount.

Finally, you are able to set the list of classes which may receive the discount. This might be every class you run, just your computer courses, or just one course you choose. This gives you flexibility to offer discounts where you think they will be appropriate, useful and affordable. You may be able to offer lower discounts to outsourced courses given your margins or it may not be helpful to offer seniors discounts to pre-natal sessions.

caption.para: Applying a concession automatically to an enrolment

section.para: With all this flexibility, you can offer discounts to your students in exactly the way you choose. For instance:

listitem.para: all students under 25 receive 10% off all courses – these are often people with lower disposable income and discounts are a useful way to attract them
all students who attended a course last term automatically get 20% off selected courses this term
all students with a senior's card receive a $20 discount off any of the daytime arts and craft classes

section.para: Generally, concessions apply on a long term basis and are based on your college's fees and charges policy. Concessions are automatically applied to fees on enrolment if a student meets the conditions you have set. If you wish to give a special deal to a certain group of people for a limited time only, it is more suitable to create a promotion.

section.title: Defining concession card types
section.para: You can define the concession types that are accepted at your college. Some of these may be accepted by student's self identifying their possession of these cards during online enrolment, others may only be available by setting the concession card against the student's record by an onCourse user.

To define the cards you accept, go to File > Preferences > Concession Types. By clicking on the add + button you can define new types, or modify existing types by doubling clicking on the record to edit it.
When you define a concession type, you have the following options:
- Available on the website. This means you will allow students to self identify the possession of this card. Note the website can not perform validation of card types - this is an honour system.

- Allow entry of concession card number. This makes the supply of a card number mandatory. Again, note there is no validation on this field - users can still enter any data they like. Useful for ensuring that only card holders self identify - you can use this data to conduct random spot checks if required.
- Has expiry date. Requiring this field means that the concession recorded against the student will no longer work automatically for discounts after the identified expiry date has past.
Once you have set your concession card types, you can add them to the discount policies you create when defining on the student tab who the discount may apply to.

section.title: Accessing concession card discounts in onCourse through Quick Enrol
section.para: If you have set the discount to 'apply automatically' and the student and their chosen class meet the requirements of the discount, it will be applied by default on enrolment. If the student is eligible for multiple discount types, the discount that provides the lowest cost to the student will be applied.
During the enrolment process, discounts that require a promotional code can be entered on the payment screen. Again, any eligible classes will have their fee reduced.
Before saving and confirming the enrolment, you can check the discounts that have been applied by hovering over the notification icon next to the class fee.
You can also manually adjust a discount as necessary by replacing the discount amount in the enrolment window.

caption.para: This student is eligible for a staff discount when they enrol in this class as they have the staff concession card on their record and this class has that discount type available

section.title: Concession card discounts on the web
section.para: If you wish, discount rates and fees can be displayed inline with the class fee on the website. When users hover over the discounted fee, they can see who is eligible to apply for it. You may choose to combine your discounts so multiple concession types can access the same reduced fee. E.g. if both seniors and students are eligible for a 10% discount, you may call the discounted fee Seniors/Students and holders of either a student card or a seniors card can be eligible to access that rate. This prevents you from showing the same discounted fee multiple times in the class.

caption.para: A class showing multiple discounts options available to concession card holders

section.para: When a student is completing the enrolment process, by default they will be charged the full fee. If you allow the entry of the concession card details via the website, they can then select the option during enrolment to select a concession card type and enter the appropriate details you require.

While concession card numbers and validity can't be checked by the website enrolment process, all students must confirm that their claim to access the concession is valid and that their details may be checked. You should ensure your enrolment policy and procedures includes information about how additional charges will be levied if students can not produce their concession card on request.

caption.para: During website enrolment, students can enter concession card details
The appropriate fee discounts are then calculated prior to the student making payment for their enrolment(s)

section.title: What is a promotion?
section.para: Promotions are another type of discount with a string attached. The student must know a particular word or code in order to obtain the discount. You might decide to perform a letterbox drop in a particular area with postcard sized teasers for your new dance classes. They explain that the recipient can get a 5% discount by going to the web site and typing in ‘WALTZ'. When they do this, the web site alters and shows the courses with fees crossed out and the discounted price alongside in red. The idea is to:

listitem.para: create the feeling of an offer targeted to a particular group of people, so the recipient feels special.
track the effectiveness of your letterbox drop
use an expiry date to create urgency
micro-market: use different strategies for different demographics

section.para: You might distribute your promotional codes by using:

listitem.para: targeted printed material
an email mailout to existing or potential students
SMS
an alliance with a club or user group – such as a deal with a local RSL that gives their members a discount through a code in their newsletter

section.para: Remember, the point of promotional codes is not to keep the code secret and prevent recipients telling their friends about it. The effectiveness of your marketing is greatly enhanced by potential students telling as many people as possible about this great deal they can get by typing in a ‘secret code'.

section.title: Accessing promotional code discounts in onCourse through Quick Enrol
Promotional codes on the web
section.para: Promotional codes are applied differently on the website to discounts that relate to concessions. Firstly, you need to ensure that your website design includes a specification for the location of the 'My discounts' option. This panel allows students to enter a promotional code that will then be applied to all eligible classes across your website during their browsing of your programs.

caption.para: Mechanism for students to enter a known promotional code to reduce eligible enrolment fees

section.para: Once a student has entered a valid promotional code, classes they view will show the full fee crossed out and the fee that applies during the promotion displayed instead. During enrolment, this discounted fee will be automatically applied.

listitem.para: A discount value may be applied in dollars, percentage or a fixed dollar amount (where you specify the total discounted class fee). All discount values are ex gst.

varlistentry.term: Who is Eligible for a discount?

orderedlist.title: Discount eligibility may be checked against any or all of the following discount parameters, all of which can be set in the discount feature in onCourse:

listitem.para: Students: Discounts may be offered to anyone, students under or over a certain age, students in a certain postcode, students with particular memberships such as staff member, or students with a concession such as a youth card.
Classes: Discounts may be offered to a Course (and all it's classes), a Class or, all current and pending classes.
Discount values: The discount itself may have a valid from or expiry date, or require students to enter a promo code
There are two main types of discounts for eligible enrolments.

Discounts not offered automatically: If a student does not know about a discount, they won't get it. If they know about it, they should enter a Promo Code. The discount value should include a promo code and obviously marketing of this promotion will need to include the promo code.
Discounts offered automatically: If a student is eligible for a discount, the discount will automatically be offered.The discount value does not include a Promo Code.

section.para: Please note that your website may not currently have a box for students to enter a promo code because this is something that may not have been required at the time of website implementation.However this is something that can be added, should you choose to offer discounts only when students enter a promo code.

section.title: Create a discount
section.para: In this example we will set up a concession for seniors card holders:

listitem.para: Select Discount from the splash screen or Courses menu.
Select + button from the bottom left of the window
In the new window, enter a name for this concession e.g. Seniors Card Concession (you can define concession types here)

There are two different types of discounts you can create. You can discount the course or purchase by a percentage of it's total or by a pre determined dollar value. To set a 10% discount, select the Discount Percent option and type 10 into the discount value field.
You can also set a minimum and maximum amount for the concession e.g. min $1 and max $10.
Setting a valid from and valid to date is optional. If you want to make the discount apply at all times, leave this field blank.

Choose if this concession can be given with other concessions. For example a student could receive this concession and a further fee discount by using a special promotional code if you check this box.

section.para: The next options allow you to select who and how this concession will apply:

listitem.para: Enrolled within # Days (the student has enrolled at the college in the past # days)
Age over/under # ages in years
With xx concession (student has supplied xx concession card type and reference number on enrolment)
Postcode or Area (where the student lives)

section.para: In this example, you might select the third option With Aged Pensioner concession or with Seniors card concession or you could set it to Age over 55.

listitem.para: The last field allows you to assign this concession to certain available classes. You can add or remove classes by using the + and – signs to the right, including allowing this concession in all current and future classes.

section.para: Promotions
In this example we will create a last minute discount for our previously enrolled students.

listitem.para: Create a code for your promotion. This will be what students enter on your website to access the promotional discount (or can be entered by your enrolment staff with phone, mail or in person enrolments).
Name and describe your promotion.
Set the amount and valid to and from dates as per concession instructions above. In this example we have limited the date to a one week range.
This promotion is for re-enrolling students, so we have set it to students who have enrolled within 60 days.

Select your eligible classes. Generally promotions are limited to a few select programs, such as those which already are over the minimum required, or dance classes or those which are starting in the next two weeks.

section.para: Don't forget, promotional codes only work if you market them. You can always email or sms special promotions to your students to get them out there quickly. With most promotions you would not want to set a qualifier, like enrolled within x days, as you want as many people as possible to ‘use' the special code to enrol in your classes, and hope the students you market the promotion to assist you in your marketing efforts by passing the deal on to their friends.

section.title: What is a membership?
section.para: Memberships can be purchased and then their related discounts may apply to the membership holder, or people related to the membership holder e.g. all staff or a business who own a corporate membership. These discounts are usually offered automatically on enrolment where someone meets the membership criteria

section.title: Creating a membership
section.para: Memberships can be created from the Marketing > Membership option. A membership needs a name and should have a description so potential purchasers understand the benefits of the membership.

A membership may have a fee to purchase, or could be given away for free. The membership will have a duration of either a set number of days from purchase, the beginning of the calendar or financial year or be for life.

caption.para: A membership product available for sale

section.para: You can choose to make the membership available for purchase online, or only via internal purchase,
At this point, you may choose to link to existing discount policies, or you may prefer to define the discounts that apply to people who hold this membership type later.

An important distinction of membership discounts is that they can also apply across relationships. For example, a company could purchase a membership and the discount policy for that membership may apply to all staff of that company who enrol.

caption.para: A membership discount policy that applies the discount to the staff members of the membership holder

section.title: Purchasing a membership
section.para: A membership can be purchased from Quick Enrol, either in conjunction with an enrolment or as a standalone purchase.
If the membership is purchased in conjunction with an enrolment that is eligible for a discount for members, then the discount will be applied at the time of purchase.

Memberships can be purchased by choosing the add membership options from the top right hand corner of the Quick Enrol window. Type the name of the membership in the product field and the rest of the membership record will be automatically filled.

caption.para: A student purchasing a membership and being eligible for the 100% discount policy at the same time.

section.title: Redeeming a membership
section.para: For as long as the membership is valid, any applicable discounts will be given automatically when the student enrols. Discounts will no longer be given if a membership has expired. Current and expired memberships can be seen in the student's general tab of their record.

example.title: How to create a membership discount
example.para: in this example we will create a membership students can buy to entitle them to a 100% discount for any of our computer classes for the next six months.

listitem.para: Open the membership window and create the membership for purchase. Set a cost for purchase and the duration of the membership in days.
Open the discount window and create the discount policy for computer club members. The discount is for 100% and will be offered automatically.

Go to the students tab of the discount window and select the options 'students with' and 'with following memberships' and add the new membership you just set up. In this instance we will choose to apply this discount only to the student who purchased it.
Go to the classes tab on the discount window and add all your current and pending computer classes.
Save and close the record. The membership is now ready for purchase and the discount policy as defined will be applied.

section.title: Reporting on discount use
section.para: The Discounts by Class report is available from the classes menu. This report shows you for each class selected, how many enrolments you have processed at full fee and any applicable discount, and the total value of any discounts applied.
